name: Construct/Deconstruct
description:
This Kata is an attempt at introducing case classes ***constructors*** and ***extractors***. --- * Let's start with an alternative constructor: Given the following case class, ```scala case class Person(name: String, age: Int, gender: Gender) ``` can you provide an additional constructor which expects a first name and a last name, (instead of the full name) and joins them into a name, such that: ```scala Person("James", "Smith", 27, Male) == Person("James Smith", 27, Male) ```
Note that even if there are ways to achieve this using *classic classes* constructors, there is an elegant and dedicated way of doing this for case classes.
--- * Let's then make it possible to provide an optional field with a default value: Let's refine the `Person` case class with an optional parameter representing the person's middle name: ```scala Person("John Kennedy", 27, Male, Some("Fitzgerald")) ``` and whose value defaults to `None`, such that it remains possible to use previous constructors: ```scala Person("John Kennedy", 27, Male, None) == Person("John Kennedy", 27, Male) ``` --- * Let's define an extractor to pattern match a string as a gender: Scala provides a specific language feature that allows creating an object (that we'll call `Extractor`) which can match in our case a `String` (`"F"` or `"M"`) and extracts a `Gender` out of it, such that this pattern match expression: ```scala "F" match { case Extractor(gender) => Some(gender) case _ => None } ``` produces `Some(Female)` If the string we're trying to match represents a gender (`"F"` or `"M"`), then there is a match and `Extrator` supplies the associated value by initializing and providing the `gender` variable. --- * Let's finally define another extractor, this time, as a placeholder for extracted values: In this last part, we'll apply the extractor feature for a slightly different purpose. Instead of using the extractor to generate the object in question (previously the `Gender`), we'll use it as a place holder for the generated object's fields (here the `Person`'s `name`, `age` and `gender`): For instance: ```scala "James Johnson-30-M" match { case Person(_, age, _) if age % 10 == 0 => Some(age+5) case Person(_, age, Female) => Some(age-10) case Person(_, age, _) => Some(age) case _ => None } ``` produces `Some(35)`. Your code should be able to parse strings such as `"$name-$age-$gender"` or `"$firstName-$lastName-$age-$gender"` (gender being either `"F"` or `"M"`).
